She liked the way she was and wasn't in a hurry to make herself more like, oh, maybe like Megan? You know, the bitchy, but totally hot, cheerleader from school? But he told her that she could still be as pretty as Megan without being a total bitch. But whatever. Sam was never gonna change herself.

Once he arrived to her house, he rang the doorbell and was then let in by Sam's mother. Like Sam, she had brown hair and green eyes. But she dressed a little more femininely.

Dan went to Sam's bedroom and saw her packing her stuff into a suitcase. She and her family were about to leave on a trip to Sam's grandparents' house and would be gone a whole week. So Dan wanted to say goodbye in person, which was why he was visiting.

"Got everything?" Dan asked Sam.

"I think so." She looked a little sad, sitting down on her bed. "I wish I didn't have to go. I'd rather spend time with you."

"Oh don't worry about that," Dan said. "We'll have all the rest of summer to hang out with each other, once you get back. You're only gonna be gone a week."

She smiled. "Yeah, I guess you're right."

14212.content:
"I wish I could go with you," Dan said.

"Then why don't you?" Sam asked, as though it were no big deal.

Dan blinked. "What?"

Sam shrugged. "If you want to come, then come." She got up and called out to her mother. "Hey, Mom? Is it okay if Dan comes with us?"

"Sure!" her mother called back. "That sounds fine."

"Huh," he said, still not entirely to terms with the situation. "Well, even if your mom says okay, my mom sure won't."

A brief phone call proved him wrong. "Sure, you can go," Dan's mother told him. "You'll be back in a week? Two weeks? Ah, doesn't matter, just have fun, sweety!"

And with that, Dan was joining his best friend on a family vacation. But as soon as they got into the car, he found out something was wrong.

1422.content:
Dan helped Sam take her luggage to the living room, and that was when they heard the doorbell ring.

"I wonder who that could be," Sam said, carrying her suitcase into the room.

"I'll get it," Dan said, walking over to the front door and opening it. Standing outside was ...
1422.title: An Interruption

choices: "...didn't care about all that church stuff and were a wild party girl instead!"
14222.content:
Standing outside was Rebekah, a 14-year old girl who went to school with Dan and Sam. They didn't really associate with her, though. The sandy-blonde-haired girl was cute, but shy. And she was very conservative, keeping with the values of her church. Sometimes, Dan wondered what she'd be like if she were more wild and rebellious.

"Hello," she said, holding out a flier. "This Saturday, we're having a special service at my church. Please come and attend. Remember, Jesus loves all."

Dan grabbed the flier, but he knew he wouldn't be attending. Not his scene. "Okay, whatever," he said, sounding maybe a little too dismissive.

This made Rebekah a little ticked off. "Listen, this service might save your eternal soul. You might not want to brush it off so quickly. I wish you'd take this more seriously."

"Oh yeah? Well, I wish you ..." he began, not realizing that what he wished would actually come true!

144.content:
You and your older sister Ashley were sitting around, lounging about on the first day of summer. Both of you were dreading the arrival of your little cousin Laura. She might have been only three years younger than you, but she acted like a five year old brat with a suger rush most of the time.

It was only most of the time because there were times where she actually was a nice girl. But since you guys were family, you saw it as an act. A way for her to get it out of trouble.

Ashley wouldn't have to deal with her all summer long though, since she was going to start collage a little early. She was studying to become a writer, ironicly. She had long blonde hair, dark green eyes, a body of a cheerleader (She jogged a lot and did acrobats when she was younger and does yoga for the flexability), and was a repectable height of six foot even.

But she also had an incredible imagination. Her best subject in school was creative writing, english, and all those other classes that had to do with writing. She wasn't bad at human psychology either. And all of this was what qualified her to be a writer.

But back to the present. Both of you liked video games. So, for your last hurrah this summer, because you both knew that with Lauras arrival, your summer would be null and void, you decided to have a tournament with your sister in which the winner would get to spend the least amount of time showing Laura around town.

Ashely thougt that this would be fun, and was confident that her skills would allow her to win the prize and enjoy the last
bit of summer relaxing.

A few hours later, you guys are sitting on the couch, neck and neck. It's the last round of the final game. Which one of you wins, and what do you say in response?
